title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement lsanfilippo@mail.austral.edu.ar. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to goatR
text: outlines propose change goatR. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to goatR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to goatR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to goatR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("bdirienzo/goatR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to goatR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Security Policy

title: Introduction
text: goatR package developed assist analysis visualization environmental data, specifically focusing climate metrics precipitation temperature. package aims simplify data processing provide ready--use functions effective exploratory data analysis presentation. primary goal goatR make climate data accessible actionable researchers practitioners offering functions streamline common data manipulation tasks produce insightful visualizations.

title: Introduction
text: Data Import Cleaning: Functions easily load clean meteorological datasets, temperature precipitation data, ensuring data consistent ready analysis. Visualization Tools: Pre-built functions creating informative plots, including monthly temperature precipitation visualizations. Summary Statistics: Tools generating tables reports key statistics, helping users quickly assess trends anomalies climate data.

title: Introduction
text: quick demonstration core functionalities goatR. walk load dataset, clean , visualize data.

what: Example: Loading and Plotting Climate Data
title: Introduction
text: data loaded, can proceed visualize using built-plotting functions.   functions provide easy way generate consistent, publication-quality graphics help understanding seasonal monthly trends climate data.
code: # Download datasets download_datasets() #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0472.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0910.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0046.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0098.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0437.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/metadatos_completos.csv # Load sample dataset NH0472 <- read_datasets("NH0472") # Plot monthly precipitation goatR::monthly_precipitation_plot(NH0472) # Plot monthly temperature goatR::monthly_temperature_plot(NH0472)

title: Introduction
text: addition visualizations, goatR also allows generate summary tables provide key insights data. summary tables include information average monthly temperatures, standard deviations, statistics valuable analysis.
code: # Generate a summary table for temperature temp_summary <- goatR::temperature_summary_table(NH0472)  # Display the summary table temp_summary #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   id     average_temperature max_temperature min_temperature standard_deviation #>   <chr>                <dbl>           <dbl>           <dbl>              <dbl> #> 1 NH0472                18.0            34.8            0.55               5.94 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: total_days <int>

title: Introduction
text: goatR designed facilitate analysis climate data, providing functions help users quickly prepare, visualize, interpret environmental data. Whether researcher analyzing climate trends educator needing demonstrate climate variability, goatR offers user-friendly set tools achieve goals. learn goatR’s functionalities see detailed examples, please refer vignettes reference manual. comprehensive overview, please visit goatR documentation.

title: Introduction
text: goatR inspired design simplicity packages like ggplot2, aims bring similar level ease functionality climate data analysis.

code: @Manual{,   title = {goatR: Geographical Observations and Analysis of Temperature and Rainfall},   author = {Bernardo {Di Rienzo} and Lautaro Sanfilippo},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.0},   url = {https://bdirienzo.github.io/goatR}, }

title: Geographical Observations and Analysis of Temperature and Rainfall
text: goatR package provides comprehensive toolkit working meteorological data Argentine weather stations. includes functions download, read, analyze weather datasets, enabling users efficiently handle meteorological information research, analysis, visualization purposes. Key features package include: Data Downloading: Easily download datasets various Argentine weather stations using download_datasets(). Specify station ID download data specific station download available datasets . Data Reading: Import downloaded datasets R read_datasets(). function allows reading data station ID specified file path, facilitating integration weather data workflow. Data Analysis: Monthly Precipitation Plot: Visualize total monthly precipitation across multiple weather stations monthly_precipitation_plot(). function aggregates precipitation data creates grouped bar chart, allowing customization colors titles. Monthly Temperature Plot: Generate line plots visualize monthly average temperature multiple stations monthly_temperature_plot(). function organizes data month allows custom color settings station. Temperature Summary Table: Summarize temperature data statistics station using temperature_summary_table(). provides statistics average, maximum, minimum, standard deviation, total number days data. goatR package simplifies process obtaining working meteorological data, particularly researchers, climatologists, data enthusiasts interested Argentine weather patterns. streamlining data access providing user-friendly functions, package enables users focus analysis rather data preparation.

title: Geographical Observations and Analysis of Temperature and Rainfall

what: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
title: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
text: function download_datasets() downloads CSV file remote repository, containing data selected Argentine weather station. user can specify weather station providing valid identifier. custom path specified, function save file default "datasets-raw" folder within current working directory. id_station specified, 5 downloaded.

title: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
text: id_station string representing identifier desired weather station. Valid options include: "NH0472", "NH0910", "NH0046", "NH0098", "NH0437". identifier constructs download URL, identifiers accepted. id_station specified, function download 5 files. path optional file path downloaded file saved. default, file saved "datasets-raw" folder within current working directory, file name based station identifier.

title: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
text: .csv file located specified default path, containing data selected weather station. string representing path .csv file saved

title: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
text: path parameter specified, function creates "datasets-raw" folder working directory (already exist) saves dataset using format "datasets-raw/<id_station>.csv". WARNING: function may overwrite existing datasets file name exists specified path!

title: Download a dataset from an Argentine weather station — download_datasets
code: # Download the dataset with ID "NH0472" to the default "datasets-raw" folder download_datasets("NH0472") #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0472.csv #> [1] "datasets-raw/NH0472.csv"  # Use the id_station directly in read_datasets to load the data data <- read_datasets(id_station = "NH0472")  # Download the dataset with ID "NH0910" to a specified custom location if (!dir.exists("./custom_folder")) {   dir.create("./custom_folder")} download_datasets("NH0910", "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv") #> File downloaded successfully to: ./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv #> [1] "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv" data <- read_datasets(path = "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv") download_datasets("NH0910", "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv") #> File downloaded successfully to: ./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv #> [1] "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv"  # Download all available datasets to the default "datasets-raw" folder download_datasets() #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0472.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0910.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0046.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0098.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0437.csv #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/metadatos_completos.csv

what: Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata
title: Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata
text: dataset contains metadata various weather monitoring stations, including locations, types, operational details. useful resource researchers interested geospatial temporal analysis weather data collection across different provinces.

title: Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata
Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata
text: data frame following columns: id Character. Unique identifier monitoring station (e.g., "A872999"). nombre Character. Name station, often indicating function affiliation (e.g., "Instituto de Clima y Agua"). tipo Character. type weather monitoring equipment (e.g., "Nimbus THP"). localidad Character. locality town station located (e.g., "Hurlingham"). provincia Character. Province station located (e.g., "Buenos Aires", "La Pampa"). lat Numeric. Latitude station decimal degrees (e.g., "-36.54"). lon Numeric. Longitude station decimal degrees (e.g., "-63.99"). altura Numeric. Altitude station sea level, meters (e.g., "165.0"). ubicacion Character. Additional descriptive information location, often including addresses notable landmarks (e.g., "Jardin Botanico Ragonese INTA"). desde POSIXct. Date station started operations, formatted ISO 8601 (e.g., "2000-01-04T00:00:00Z"). hasta POSIXct. Date station ended operations (applicable), formatted ISO 8601 (e.g., "2024-05-23T00:00:00Z").

title: Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata
text: row dataset represents unique weather monitoring station. data includes spatial temporal coverage, can used mapping analyzing operational status weather stations across different regions.

title: Metadata of Weather Monitoring Stations — metadata

CP: 6326 2010-09-13T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872822           Ruta Nac. Nº35 Km.535 CP: 6270 2010-09-06T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872821         Ruta Nac. Nº35 Km. 110. CP: 8206 2010-09-10T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872819 Ruta Nº 77, km.20. CP:7607 Gral Alvarado 2010-11-11T00:00:00Z[UTC] #>                             hasta #> A872999 2024-05-23T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872834 2024-03-23T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872823 2024-06-18T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872822 2022-11-02T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872821 2022-06-15T00:00:00Z[UTC] #> A872819 2024-02-01T00:00:00Z[UTC]  # Example: Plotting the stations on a map using latitude and longitude if (requireNamespace("ggplot2", quietly = TRUE)) {   library(ggplot2)   ggplot(metadata, aes(x = lon, y = lat)) +     geom_point() +     labs(title = "Locations of Weather Monitoring Stations",          x = "Longitude", y = "Latitude") } #> Want to understand how all the pieces fit together? Read R for Data #> Science: https://r4ds.hadley.nz/

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
text: Generates bar plot illustrating total monthly precipitation across multiple weather stations.

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
code: monthly_precipitation_plot(   ...,   colors = NULL,   title = "Accumulated Precipitation by Month" )

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
text: ... One data frames, containing data weather station. data frame must include following columns: fecha Date precipitation measurement. format coercible Date. id Identifier weather station. precipitacion_pluviometrica Numeric value representing precipitation millimeters. can pass multiple data frames separated commas, e.g., "station1", "station2", "station3" colors Optional. character vector specifying colors use station plot. provided, function generate set dark colors automatically. vector either named station IDs length matching number stations. title Optional. string specifying title plot. Defaults "Accumulated Precipitation Month".

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
text: ggplot object representing total monthly precipitation station.

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
text: function accepts one data frames, representing data different weather station. aggregates monthly precipitation data visualizes using grouped bar chart. Users can customize plot colors title needed.

title: Monthly Precipitation Plot — monthly_precipitation_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Assuming you have two data frames: station1 and station2 plot <- monthly_precipitation_plot(station1, station2, title = "Monthly Precipitation") print(plot) } # }

what: Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
title: Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
text: function creates line plot showing monthly average temperature measurements ("temperatura_abrigo_150cm") multiple Argentine weather stations.

title: Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
text: ... One data frames, containing data weather station. data frame must include following columns: fecha: Date column ("Date" character) representing date observation. id: Character factor column serving unique identifier weather station. temperatura_abrigo_150cm: Numeric column representing temperature measurement 150 cm height. can pass multiple data frames separated commas, e.g., "station1", "station2", "station3". colors named vector specifying colors use station plot. names correspond station IDs. NULL, set dark colors generated automatically. title title plot. Defaults "Temperature" specified.

title: Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
text: ggplot object representing monthly average temperature plot.

title: Generate a Monthly Average Temperature Plot for Multiple Stations — monthly_temperature_plot
text: function performs following steps: Validates inputs data frames contain required columns. Converts "fecha" column "Date" type necessary. Extracts month "fecha" column orders according calendar. Calculates monthly average temperature station. Generates line plot points, coloring station differently. RECOMMENDATION: Use function conjunction functions available @seealso

what: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
title: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
text: read_datasets() function reads CSV file containing meteorological data specific weather station. function loads data global environment, allowing analysis manipulation.

title: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
text: id_station string representing identifier desired weather station, path provided. Valid identifiers include: "NH0472", "NH0910", "NH0046", "NH0098", "NH0437". parameter used construct path CSV file. path optional string specifying file path CSV file read. provided, id_station ignored.

title: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
text: data frame containing weather station data file successfully read.

title: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
text: function designed work conjunction download_datasets(), downloads saves weather station data. three ways use function: Using download_datasets() default path: file saved default "datasets-raw" folder, need provide id_station parameter read file. Using custom path: saved file custom folder, provide complete file path using path parameter. Using return value download_datasets(): can store path returned download_datasets() variable pass read_datasets() via path parameter.

title: Read a downloaded dataset from an Argentine weather station — read_datasets
code: # Use download_datasets() with default path, then read using id_station download_datasets("NH0472") #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0472.csv #> [1] "datasets-raw/NH0472.csv" data <- read_datasets(id_station = "NH0472")  # Use a custom path download_datasets("NH0910", "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv") #> File downloaded successfully to: ./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv #> [1] "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv" data <- read_datasets(path = "./custom_folder/NH0910_data.csv")  # Store the path from download_datasets() and use it directly in read_datasets() file_path <- download_datasets("NH0046") #> File downloaded successfully to: datasets-raw/NH0046.csv data <- read_datasets(path = file_path)

title: Sample Weather Observation Data — station_sample
text: dataset, named station_sample, provides daily weather observations specific weather monitoring station (NH0472). includes various meteorological variables temperature, wind speed, radiation. serves resource climate studies analysis day--day weather patterns.

title: Sample Weather Observation Data — station_sample
text: data frame following columns: id Character. Identifier weather station (e.g., "NH0472"). fecha Date. Observation date YYYY-MM-DD format (e.g., "1961-07-01"). temperatura_abrigo_150cm Numeric. Temperature 150 cm shelter, degrees Celsius (e.g., "11.1"). temperatura_abrigo_150cm_maxima Numeric. Maximum daily temperature 150 cm shelter, degrees Celsius (e.g., "13.4"). temperatura_abrigo_150cm_minima Numeric. Minimum daily temperature 150 cm shelter, degrees Celsius (e.g., "8.8"). temperatura_intemperie_5cm_minima Numeric. Minimum daily temperature 5 cm open air, degrees Celsius (e.g., "6.2"). temperatura_intemperie_50cm_minima Numeric. Minimum daily temperature 50 cm open air, degrees Celsius (e.g., "4.5"). temperatura_suelo_5cm_media Numeric. Average daily soil temperature 5 cm depth, degrees Celsius (e.g., "10.0"). temperatura_suelo_10cm_media Numeric. Average daily soil temperature 10 cm depth, degrees Celsius (e.g., "9.8"). temperatura_inte_5cm Numeric. Temperature 5 cm cover, degrees Celsius (e.g., "7.3"). temperatura_intemperie_150cm_minima Numeric. Minimum daily temperature 150 cm open air, degrees Celsius. humedad_suelo Numeric. Soil humidity percentage. precipitacion_pluviometrica Numeric. Daily rainfall mm. granizo Logical. Indicator hail occurrence (TRUE/FALSE). nieve Logical. Indicator snow occurrence (TRUE/FALSE). heliofania_efectiva Numeric. Effective sunshine duration hours. heliofania_relativa Numeric. Relative sunshine duration percentage. tesion_vapor_media Numeric. Average daily vapor tension hPa. humedad_media Numeric. Average daily humidity percentage (e.g., "75.3"). humedad_media_8_14_20 Numeric. Average humidity 8 , 2 PM, 8 PM. rocio_medio Numeric. Average daily dew point temperature degrees Celsius. duracion_follaje_mojado Numeric. Duration wet foliage hours. velocidad_viento_200cm_media Numeric. Average wind speed 2 m height m/s. direccion_viento_200cm Numeric. Wind direction 2 m height degrees north. velocidad_viento_1000cm_media Numeric. Average wind speed 10 m height m/s. direccion_viento_1000cm Numeric. Wind direction 10 m height degrees north. velocidad_viento_maxima Numeric. Maximum daily wind speed, m/s (e.g., "8.5"). presion_media Numeric. Average daily atmospheric pressure, hPa (e.g., "1015.6"). radiacion_global Numeric. Global radiation kJ/m² (e.g., "520.3"). radiacion_neta Numeric. Net radiation kJ/m² (e.g., "300.4"). evaporacion_tanque Numeric. Daily tank evaporation mm (e.g., "2.5"). evapotranspiracion_potencial Numeric. Potential evapotranspiration mm (e.g., "4.0"). profundidad_napa Numeric. Depth water table meters (e.g., "1.8"). horas_frio Numeric. Total daily cold hours (e.g., "15.6"). unidad_frio Numeric. Unit cold hours, applicable (e.g., "-").

title: Temperature Summary Table — temperature_summary_table
text: Generates summary table temperature data multiple stations.

title: Temperature Summary Table — temperature_summary_table
text: ... One data frames representing temperature data various stations. data frame contain: "id": representing station identifiers. "temperatura_abrigo_150cm": representing temperature measurements height 150 cm.

title: Temperature Summary Table — temperature_summary_table
text: data frame summarizing temperature statistics station, including: Average temperature ('average_temperature') Maximum temperature ('max_temperature') Minimum temperature ('min_temperature') Standard deviation temperature ('standard_deviation') Total number days temperature data ('total_days')

title: Temperature Summary Table — temperature_summary_table
text: function temperature_summary_table() takes one data frames input, containing temperature data different weather stations, returns summary temperature statistics station. required columns : "id" station identifiers "temperatura_abrigo_150cm" temperature measurements 150 cm height. function combines input data frames single data frame, validates required columns present, groups data station ID compute summary statistics. input data frame lacks required columns "id" "temperatura_abrigo_150cm", function stop error message. WARNING: function stop required columns found data frames provided.

title: Temperature Summary Table — temperature_summary_table
code: # Example of using temperature_summary_table with two data frames df1 <- data.frame(id = c(1, 1, 2, 2), temperatura_abrigo_150cm = c(15, 18, 20, 22)) df2 <- data.frame(id = c(1, 3, 3, 3), temperatura_abrigo_150cm = c(17, 21, 19, 16)) temperature_summary_table(df1, df2) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>      id average_temperature max_temperature min_temperature standard_deviation #>   <dbl>               <dbl>           <dbl>           <dbl>              <dbl> #> 1     1                16.7              18              15               1.53 #> 2     2                21                22              20               1.41 #> 3     3                18.7              21              16               2.52 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: total_days <int>
